filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions of three copies of The [First] Book of Urizen. Copies A, C, and F were beautifully and extensively color printed in the same printing session in 1794. This is the first time that Copies C and F have been reproduced, and the first reproduction of Copy A since 1929.
Copies A and C are in the Yale Center for British Art, Yale University, and Copy F is in the Houghton Library, Harvard University. These three copies join Copy G, from the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress, and together comprise half the extant copies of The [First] Book of Urizen. Two other copies of Urizen, Copy D, from the 1794 printing and Copy B from the 1795 printing, are forthcoming.
Blake etched in shallow relief the twenty-eight plates of The [First] Book of Urizen in 1794, although only Copies A and B contain them all. In the same year, he printed proof Copies H and I (only 3 and 2 plates respectively) and Copies A, C, D, E, F, and J. Copy B was printed the following year as part of a set of large-paper copies of the illuminated books and Copy G was printed in 1818. Plate 4 appears only in Copies A-C (an impression was pulled for Copy G but not included). The full-page designs are differently positioned in each copy; Copies A, B, E, and F also have variant orders of text plates.
The electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4x5" transparencies; text and images are fully searchable and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates. With the Archive's recently added comparison feature, users can easily juxtapose multiple impressions of any plate across the different copies of an illuminated book. New protocols for transcription, which produce improved accuracy and fuller documentation in editors' notes, have been applied to all the Urizen texts, including previously published Copy G.
With the publication of these three copies, the Archive now contains fully searchable and scalable electronic editions of 48 copies of 18 of Blake's 19 illuminated books in the context of full bibliographic information about each work, careful diplomatic transcriptions of all texts, detailed descriptions of all images, and extensive bibliographies. They also join the Thomas Butts set of Blake's watercolors illustrating the Book of Job, and Blake's twelve water-color illustrations to John Milton's poems "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso," the first of several series of Milton illustrations that we will be adding in Preview mode. In the near future we expect to release more drawings and prints in Preview mode, which provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote, a much-anticipated electronic edition of Jerusalem Copy E, and further supplementary materials, including a biography and glossary.
The editors of the Archive recently photographed 125 works by Blake in the Department of Prints and Drawings, National Gallery of Art, Washington D. C., including biblical watercolors, pencil drawings, and proofs in various states of the Job engravings. We have obtained reproductions of the Blake collections of the Fogg Museum of Art, Victoria and Albert Museum, the Metropolitan Museum, National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne, and the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery. Over the next few years, we will be adding to the Archive these extensive collections of books, prints, and drawings, many of which will be reproduced in color for the first time.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, by a major grant from the Preservation and Access Division of the National Endowment for the Humanities, by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objinfo.watermark: I TaylorThe watermark appears only on Object 20 (Bentley Plate 15). Bentley page 169, note 1, points out that the paper on which Objects 6 and 12 (Bentley Plates 4 and 8) are printed is "conspicuously heavier" than other leaves.
objinfo.pennednumbers: Objects 2, 6, 8, and 28 (Bentley Plates 2, 4, 5, and 27) are numbered 1, 3, 6, and 24 top right in red ink.Partly erased numbers or fragments of numbers appear top right on Objects 3, 4, 5, 7, 9, 15, and 21 (Bentley Plates 22, 24, 3, 12, 6, 14, and 23); other plates show evidence of erasure.

provenance.name: Yale Center for British Art
provenance.note: Possibly acquired from Blake by Thomas (first Baron) Dimsdale; by inheritance to Major T. E. Dimsdale, who sold the volume at Sotheby's, 28 Feb. 1956, lot 531 (£6800 to Howard Samuel); sold by Samuel through the New York dealer John Fleming to Paul Mellon in 1958; given by Mellon to the Yale Center for British Art in 1992.

desc.objtitle: THE FIRST BOOK of URIZENThe Book of Urizen, The [First] Book of Urizen, Object 1 (Bentley 1, Erdman 1, Keynes 1)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a rigidly symmetrical composition, a willow-like tree with at most a few leaves forms a cave-like arch over the top half of the plate. The words of the title appear between the branches. A fully gowned old man with closed eyes and long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits cross-legged on a large book in the center foreground. Centered behind him is a pair of stone tablets with arched tops, like tombstones. Indeterminate dark forms, perhaps another arching tree, appear above and on both sides of the tablets. Lying on the ground to the man's left and right are two sets of quadrangular stone tablets or books or, alternatively, the ends of a single long tablet, perhaps a coffin lid. The dark background, trees, and tablets taken together suggest a graveyard setting. Beneath Urizen's feet is an open book. The toes of his right foot emerge from his beard to mark his place in the book. Tree roots sprout to left and right in the foreground beneath the book and tablets. Holding a writing instrument in each hand and resting his arms on the tablets to his left and right, Urizen seems to be copying from the book onto the tablets. The instruments may be quills, graphite pencils, or etching needles. Publication information is centered beneath the book.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits facing forward, legs crossed, on a book. With both hands, a writing instrument in each, he copies from the book onto stone tablets to his right and left with his arms resting on the tablets. The toes of his right foot mark his place in the book. His eyes are closed or looking sharply downward.

A willow-like tree on the left forms a cave-like arch over the top half of the plate that tightly encloses the tombstone-like tablets behind Urizen. There may be a few leaves on the branches near their termination on the right. Above the tablets are indeterminate dark forms that may be another arching tree. The words of the title appear between the branches of the tree growing from the left side of the design. Publication information appears between roots that sprout to left and right at the bottom of the plate.
A large open book on the ground provides a platform for Urizen to sit cross-legged on as he copies its text, which is represented by indecipherable marks.
Urizen holds instruments in both hands that may be quill pens, graphite pencils, or etching needles.

A stone tablet, or two tablets one on top of the other, or stacks of books, provides one of the two surfaces on which Urizen writes. There may be only one tablet with its two ends showing. Its position and material suggest a coffin lid of some sort.
A pair of upright tablets resembling tombstones and the tablets of the decalogue sit directly behind Urizen.
The setting altogether suggests a graveyard.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Extensions of the letters of "URIZEN" (line 4) suggest vines, including a loopy spiral introducing the first letter.

component.illusobjdesc: Extensions of the letters of "URIZEN" (line 4) suggest vines, including a loopy spiral introducing the first letter.

desc.objtitle: PRELUDIUM TO THE BOOK OF URIZEN, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young woman wearing a full gown floats horizontally in a blue-green sky above the text. The woman fully extends her left arm parallel to the line of her body to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown.

component.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young female wearing a full, flowing gown hovers horizontally in a blue-green sky. She fully extends her left arm parallel to the line of her body to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown. Her hair may be short; she may be wearing a close-fitting cap on the top of her head. Alternatively, her hair may be piled on top of her head and arranged into a bun. Her right foot is prominent.
A naked infant, whose arm is held by a female, floats horizontally in line with her arm. Both arms are extended horizontally.
Flames, or flame-like vegetation, surround the text on all sides.
Flames, or flame-like vegetation, surround the text on all sides.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Right of the "N" of "URIZEN" (line 6) there is a falling figure. A loopy vine-like extension on the "y" of "solitary" (line 10) separates the stanzas from one another. A large leaf grows from the "D" of "Dictate" (line 12) and a vine extends from the "y" of "your" (line 13).

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the "N" of "URIZEN" (line 6) is a falling figure, with its arms raised horizontally.

A loopy vine-like extension on the "y" of "solitary" (line 10) separates the stanzas from one another. A large leaf grows from the "D" of "Dictate" (line 12) and a vine extends from the "y" of "your" (line 13).

lg.l: PRELUDIUM
TO
THE
BOOK OFIn Copy A, the word "FIRST" preceding "BOOK OF" was not printed.
URIZEN
Of the primeval Priests assum'd power,
When Eternals spurn'd back his religion;
And gave him a place in the north,
Obscure. shadowy, void. solitary.
Eternals I hear your call gladly,
Dictate swift winged words. & fear not
To unfold your dark visions of torment.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits in a contracted position with knees drawn up to his chest, arms down at his sides. His wrists and ankles are shackled and his eyes are closed. Spiky beams of light emanate from behind his head. The dark earth tones of the background suggest a cave or other stony area.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits in a contracted position with knees drawn up to his chest, arms down at his sides. He faces forward, his head tilted slightly upward. His wrists and ankles are shackled and his eyes are closed. Spiky beams of light emanate from behind his head.
Spiky beams of light emanate from behind Urizen's head.
Urizen's wrists and ankles are shackled.
The dark earth tones of the background suggest a cave or other stony area.

l.note: In Copy A, the plate number "15" has been partly erased and is now barely legible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four human figures, probably representing the first four sons of Urizen, inhabit a compartmented landscape of sea, land, sky, and heavens. These sons of Urizen correspond to the classical elements of fire, air, earth, and water: "first Thiriel appear'd . . . Like a man from a cloud born, & Utha / From the waters emerging . . . Grodna rent the deep earth howling . . . then Fuzon / Flam'd out" (Plate 24, lines 13-21). Clockwise from the top: (1) Fire/Fuzon: A figure in flames, probably male, hovers horizontally, facing out toward the viewer with arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees. His position and the curved lower edge of the space he occupies suggest the sun. (2) Air/Thiriel: Just below Fire, with nude body in an upward curve that reinforces the suggestion of a sun above, hovers a second figure, apparently male, with his hands raised to his chest and palms turned out. Between these upper two figures and the lower two is a curving, horizontal line of cloud. (3) Earth/Grodna: At lower right crouches a nude male with short hair, head up, mouth open, and hands on the ground. There are slight suggestions of a short beard on his chin and left cheek. He seems to be emerging from the earth, represented by a wave- washed island or peninsula of land. (4) Water/Utha: At lower left, the upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. Above his head may be some vegetation-covered land.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure in flames, probably male, hovers horizontally, facing out toward the viewer with arms and hands upraised between the horizontal and 135 degrees, palms out. His hair is flame-like and his mouth is slightly open. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Fuzon, and the classical element fire. The curved shape delimited by the top two figures suggests the sun.
Flames envelop a hovering male figure, Fuzon/fire. Their shape helps to suggest the sun.

Just below the figure of Fuzon/fire, with nude body in an upward curve that reinforces the suggestion of a sun above, hovers a figure apparently male, with short, curly hair, mouth open, and hands raised, palms out. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Thiriel, and the classical element air.
A line of cloud divides the top two figures from the bottom two.
An area of sky cut by a horizontal cloud is the transitional zone between fire and air (above) and water and earth (below).

A nude male with short hair, head up, mouth open, and hands on the ground crouches, positioned as if emerging from the earth. There are slight suggestions of a short beard on his chin and left cheek. He apparently represents one of the first sons of Urizen, Grodna, and the classical element earth.
Grodna emerges from the surface of a wave-washed island or peninsula of land.
The green coloring of the earth below the figure lower right and above the head of the figure lower left suggests some sort of vegetation, possibly grass.
The head of Utha emerges from an area of dark water, which washes up in waves on an area of land.
The upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. He seems to be one of the first sons of Urizen, Utha, and the classical element water.

l.note: In Copy A, the plate number "22" has been partly erased; the second digit in the plate number is barely legible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short bushy hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread. Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, his entire body.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short bushy hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread.
Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, the figure's entire body.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate—with at least one flowery stem just to the left, large leaves below the left column of text, and a stem of buds, flowers, or leaves below the right column—also sends out tendrils that separate the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, usually but not always continuous with the central plant, separate most of the stanzas. Other stanzas are separated by flying insects and birds, sometimes in combination with the vegetation (as between stanzas 1 and 2 and 2 and 3 of chapter 2 in the right column).

component.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate—with at least one flowery stem just to the left, large leaves below the left column of text, and a stem of buds, flowers, or leaves below the right column—also sends out tendrils that separate the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, usually but not always continuous with the central plant, separate most of the stanzas and fill spaces at the ends of lines and around chapter headings.
In the left column, a line of several flying birds divides the third and fourth stanzas of chapter 1; a large bird flies lower right between stanzas 2 and 3 of chapter 2.
A flying insect, with other insects (or birds) beside it, separates stanzas 1 and 2 of chapter 2.

lg.l: 1. Lo, a shadow of horror is risen
In Eternity! Unknown, unprolific?
Self-closd, all-repelling: what Demon
Hath form'd this abominable void
This soul-shudd'ring vacuum? Some
said
'It is Urizen", But unknown, abstracted
Brooding secret, the dark power hid.
2. Times on times he divided, & measur'd
Space by space in his ninefold darkness
Unseen, unknown; changes appeard
Like desolate mountains rifted furious
By the black winds of perturbation
3. For he strove in battles dire
In unseen conflictions with shapes
Bred from his forsaken wilderness.
Of beast, bird, fish, serpent & element
Combustion, blast, vapour and cloud.
4. Dark revolving in silent activity:
Unseen in tormenting passions;
An activity unknown and horrible;
A self-contemplating shadow,
In enormous labours occupied
5. But Eternals beheld his vast forests
Age on ages he lay, clos'd, unknown.
Brooding shut in the deep; all avoid
The petrific abominable chaos
6. His cold horrors silent. dark Urizen
Prepar'd; his ten thousands of thunders
Rang'd in gloom'd array stretch out across
The dread world. & the rolling of wheels
As of swelling seas, sound in his clouds
In his hills of stor'd snows, in his mountains
Of hail & ice: voices of terror,
Are heard. like thunders of autumn,
When the cloud blazes over the harvests
-tion
1. Earth was not: nor globes of attrac-
The will of the Immortal expanded
Or contracted his all flexible senses.
Death was not, but eternal life sprung
2. The sound of a trumpet the heavens
Awoke & vast clouds of blood roll'd
Round the dim rocks of Urizen, so nam'd
That solitary one in Immensity
3. Shrill the trumpet: & myriads of Eter-In Copy A, a line seems to have been drawn in ink through lines 49-50. Compare Plate 8, lines 2-3.
-nity,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits on the ground, his right leg extended to the left and his left leg bent at the knee and drawn up toward his torso. His arms are raised horizontally, with the elbows bent and his hands grasping his head, covered with short, curly hair. He faces forward but looks down. His arm gesture suggests anguish or despair. Wavy vertical lines throughout the entire design suggest either dark rain, or flames that give no light, or some compound of the two (fiery rain or raining fire?). The figure sits in a shallow depression in dark earth—one of the classical elements with which he may be identified.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male sits on the ground, his right leg extended to the left and his left leg bent at the knee and drawn up toward his torso. His arms are raised horizontally, with the elbows bent and his hands grasping his head, covered with short, curly hair. He faces forward but looks down. His arm gesture suggests anguish or despair.
Wavy vertical lines throughout the entire design suggest either dark rain, or flames that give no light, or some compound of the two (fiery rain or raining fire?).
The figure sits in a shallow depression in dark earth—one of the classical elements with which he may be identified.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender vine separates the two columns of text. Other vines, attached to the central vine or independent of it, fill spaces between stanzas. Two at the top of the plate are very worm-like. The short branch extending from the main vine left of the heading for chapter 3 (right column) may bear a flower. A serpent with open mouth faces left above the first line of the fourth stanza (left column). A bird and another flying creature—bird or insect—soar below the first line in the fourth stanza (left column). Two birds fly right of the first line of the sixth stanza (left column). A bird flying at a 45 degree angle to the left appears near the margin right of the fourth and fifth lines in the second (right) column of text. A spider stands on some vegetation or the ground right of the heading to chapter 3 (right column).

component.illusobjdesc: A slender vine separates the two columns of text. Other vines, attached to the central vine or independent of it, fill spaces between stanzas. Two at the top of the plate are very worm-like. The short branch extending from the main vine left of the heading for chapter 3 (right column) may bear a flower.
A bird and another flying creature—bird or insect—soar below the first line in the fourth stanza (left column).
A serpent with open mouth faces left above the first line of the fourth stanza (left column).
Two birds fly right of the first line of the sixth verse (left column).
A bird flying at a 45 degree angle to the left appears near the margin right of the fourth and fifth lines in the second (right) column of text.
A spider stands on some vegetation or the ground right of the heading to chapter 3 (right column).

lg.l: Muster around the bleak desarts
Now fill'd with clouds darkness & waters
That roll'd perplex'd labring & utter'd
Words articulate, bursting in thunders
That roll'd on the tops of his mountains
4. From the depths of dark solitude._
From
The eternal abode in my holiness,
Hidden, set apart in my stern counsels
Reserv'd for the days of futurity.
I have sought for a joy without pain,
For a solid without fluctuation
Why will you die O Eternals?
Why live in unquenchable burnings?
5 First I fought with the fire; consum'd
Inwards, into a deep world within:
A void immense, wild dark & deep
Where nothing was: Natures wide womb
And self balanc'd stretch'd o'er the void
I alone, even I! the winds merciless
Bound; but condensing, in torrents
They fall & fall; strong, I repell'd
The vast waves, & arose on the waters
A wide world of solid obstruction
6, Here alone I in books formd of me-
-tals
Have written the secrets of wisdom
The secrets of dark contemplation
By fightings and conflicts dire.
With terrible monsters Sin-bred:
Which the bosoms of all inhabit;
Seven deadly Sins of the soul.
7. Lo! I unfold my darkness; and on
This rock, place with strong hand the Book
Of eternal brass, written in my solitude.
8. Laws of peace, of love. of unity;
Of pity. compassion. forgiveness.
Let each chuse one habitation:
His ancient infinite mansion:
One command. one joy. one desire,
One curse, one weight, one measure
One King. one God, one Law.
1. The voice ended, they saw his pale
visage
Emerge from the darkness; his hand
On the rock of eternity unclasping
The Book of brass. Rage siez'd the strong
2. Rage, fury. intense indignation
In cataracts of fire blood & gall
In whirlwinds of sulphurous smoke:
And enormous forms of energy;

l.note: In Copy A, after line 54, the line "All the seven deadly sins of the soul" has been erased.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, floats or swims on his back in dark water cut horizontally by waves. Alternatively, he may be rising to the surface of the water from beneath. The design may depict Urizen's report that he "repell'd / The vast waves, & arose on the waters / A wide world of solid obstruction" (Plate 6, lines 24-26). His arms are raised at 135 degrees and his knees are drawn up toward his chest.

component.illusobjdesc: Seen from above, a nude old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, floats or swims on his back in dark water. Alternatively, he may be rising to the surface of the water from beneath. His arms are raised at 135 degrees and his knees are drawn up toward his chest. His hair and beard stream out into the water.
Urizen floats in what appears to be dark water cut horizontally by waves.

l.note: In Copy A, the plate number "13" has been partly erased. The transcription of the second number—"3"—is uncertain.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer squarely. Spiky beams of light radiate above his head. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks. The design may depict the moment when the Eternals "saw his pale visage / Emerge from the darkness; his hand / . . . unclasping / The Book of brass" (Plate 6, lines 46-50).

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer directly. Spiky beams of light radiate above his head. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book. He would appear to be looking down at the book. His left leg is bent at the knee and drawn up toward his chest.
Urizen holds the top corners of a large book, perhaps the Book of Brass (Plate 6), that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate sends out leaves and tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other vines or tendrils, sometimes extensions of the central plant, divide some of the stanzas. Miscellaneous birds, serpents, and human figures occupy spaces left between stanzas and at the ends of lines.

component.illusobjdesc: A plant rooted at the center bottom of the plate sends out leaves and tendrils that divide the two columns of text; other tendrils and vines, sometimes extensions of the central plant, divide some of the stanzas, most notably stanzas 3 and 4. A very long leaf takes up the space at the end of line 21.

Miscellaneous birds occupy the spaces between stanzas and at the ends of lines. In the left column, a tiny bird or insect appears between stanzas 2 and 3. A larger bird with a forked tail and wings spread appears at the ends of lines 6-8. A line of nine tiny birds divides stanzas 4 from 5. In the right column, two birds divide stanzas 7 and 8.

At the ends of lines 18-19 there are five hovering figures. The first and third figures from the left (and possibly the other three) have their arms extended. The two on the right seem to be in the "flames of Eternal fury" (line 19).
The two hovering figures on the right at the end of line 19 seem to be in the "flames of Eternal fury" (line 19).
Between lines 30 and 31 are two hovering figures. The one on the left is gowned and holds its arms extended toward the other.
Between lines 30 and 31 are two hovering figures. The one on the right is running with its arms raised horizontally.
A serpent, facing right with mouth open, appears at the end of line 42.
The tail of the "y" on "fury" at the end of line 19 turns into an especially squiggly—not exactly loopy—and vigorous separation between the stanzas at lines 19-20.

lg.l: In living creations appear'dIn Copy A, a line seems to have been drawn in ink through lines 2-3. Compare Plate 5, lines 49-50.
In the flames of eternal fury,
3. Sund'ring. dark'ning, thund'ring!
Rent away with a terrible crash
Eternity roll'd wide apart
Wide asunder rolling
Mountainous all around
Departing; departing: departing,
Leaving ruinous fragments of life
Hanging frowning cliffs & all between
An ocean of voidness unfathomable,
4. The roaring fires ran o'er the heav'ns
In whirlwinds & cataracts of blood
And o'er the dark desarts of Urizen
Fires pour thro' the void on all sides

l.note: In Copy A, the line "On Urizens self-begotten armies," between lines 16 and 17, has been erased and covered with a vine design.

lg.l: 5. But no light from the fires, all was
darkness
In the flames of Eternal fury
6. In fierce anguish & quenchless,
flames
-ging
To the desarts and rocks He ran ra-In Copy A, the word "He" in lines 23-26 and 32 seems to have been written over erasures. For further speculation, see Erdman page 805 note.
To hide, but He could not; combiningIn Copy A, the first letter of "He" in lines 24-26 was changed from a lower-case "h" to an upper-case "H."
He dug mountains & hills in vast strength
He piled them in incessant labour,
In howlings & pangs & fierce madness
Long periods in burning fires labouring
Till hoary, and age-broke, and aged.
In despair and the shadows of death.
7. And a roof vast petrific around,
On all sides He fram'd: like a womb:
Where thousands of rivers in veins
Of blood pour down the mountains to cool
The eternal fires beating without
From Eternals; & like a black globe
View'd by sons of Eternity, standing
On the shore of the infinite ocean
Like a human heart strugling & beating
The vast world of Urizen appear'd.
8. And Los round the dark globe of
Urizen,
Kept watch for Eternals to confine,
The obscure separation alone;
For Eternity stood wide apart,

objnote.p: As printed fragments indicate, two lines of text, between lines 11 and 12, have been deleted from the copperplate. Erdman notes that these lines are "almost legible in Copy B" (page 805).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three nude male figures with serpents coiled around their bodies fall downward through, and into, flames. The figure on the left faces away and clutches his head in his hands. The figure on the right also clutches his head in his hands, but he falls backward with his face up rather than down and with his body, the most contracted of the three figures, facing the viewer. The figure in the middle faces outward with his arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees (relative to his body). The serpent's left-facing head and upper body encircle the middle figure's head, and the serpent's tail similarly encircles his feet and then terminates in small coils. Two mysterious faces, perhaps of animals, appear in the flames on each side of the torso of the middle figure. These faces look leonine (right) and serpent-like (left). Four spear, dart, or arrow points and shafts appear among the flames upper right.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He faces away and clutches his head in his hands.

A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He falls backward with his face up and with his body somewhat contracted and facing the viewer. His left leg is bent at the knee and drawn up toward his torso.

A nude male figure in the coils of a serpent falls downward through, and into, flames. He faces outward, toward the viewer, with his arms raised between the horizontal and 135 degrees (relative to his body) and left foot prominently displayed. His hands are raised, palms out to the right and left. The shape made by the serpent's head and upper body suggest a halo.
A serpent coils around the body of a nude male.

A serpent coils around the body of a nude male. With jaws open, the serpent's left-facing head and upper body encircle the figure's head, and the serpent's tail similarly encircles the feet and then terminates in small coils.
A serpent coils around the body of a nude male.

Two mysterious faces appear in the flames on each side of the torso of the middle figure. The face on the left may be a serpent. The face on the right may be a man with a short, pointed beard or perhaps a lion.
The figures are surrounded by dark flames.
Four spear, arrow, or dart points and shafts appear among the flames upper right.

lg.l: As the stars are apart from the earth
9. Los wept howling around the dark
Demon:
And cursing his lot for in anguish,
Urizen was rent from his side:
And a fathomless void for his feet;
And intense fires for his dwelling.
10. But Urizen laid in a stony sleep
Unorganiz'd, rent from Eternity
11. The Eternals said; What is this? Death
Urizen is a clod of clay,

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror, perhaps depicting the moment when "Los howld in a dismal stupor" (line 1).

lg.l: 12: Los howld in a dismal stupor,
Groaning! gnashing! groaning!
Till the wrenching apart was healed
13: But the wrenching of Urizen
heal'd not
Cold, featureless, flesh or clay
Rifted with direful changes
He lay in a dreamless night
14: Till Los rouz'd his his fireIn Copy A, the "s" at the end of "fires" did not print.
affrighted
At the formless unmeasurable
death.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure with long hair, perhaps Los creating Enitharmon (or Enitharmon herself), bends forward toward the viewer over a large red globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. There is a slight indication of a sleeve at the left wrist, but the figure's back appears to be exposed in this copy. He raises his arms at 135 degrees and holds his hands vertically to his head and perhaps over his ears. Nerves, or sinews, or cords of drapery, or perhaps blood in veins stream over the figure's lower back and along what may be his legs on either side of his back. His hair, perhaps fused with the lines on his back, cascades around the globe. The design may depict the "globe of life blood" that "trembled / Branching out into roots" to embody a "female form trembling and pale . . . the first female now separate" (Plate 17, lines 3-12).

In the context of the gestation and birth metaphors of the text, the skeleton's position may suggest a fetus.

lg.l: 1: Los smitten with astonish-
Frightend at the hurtling bones
2; And at the surging sulphure-
-ous
Perturbed Immortal mad raging
3: In whirlwinds & pitch & nitre
Round the furious limbs of Los
4: And Los formed nets & gins
And threw the nets round about
5; He watch'd in shuddring fear
The dark changes & bound every
change
With rivets of iron & brass;
6, And these were the changes
of Urizen.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of stone. His left leg is placed forward and bent at the knee and his right leg extended behind, as if positioned to support the weight of the massive rock above. His arms, accordingly, are raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbows, in a position to support weight from above. His head and hands are hidden by the rock; alternatively he may be headless.

lg.l: 1 Ages on ages roll'd over him!
In stony sleep ages roll'd over him!
Like a dark waste stretching chang'able
By earthquakes riv'n, belching sullen
fires
On ages roll'd ages in ghastly
Sick torment; around him in whirlwinds
Of darkness the eternal Prophet howl'd
Beating still on his rivets of iron
Pouring sodor of iron; dividing
The horrible night into watches.
2 And Urizen (so his eternal name)
His prolific delight obscurd more & more
In dark secresy hiding in surgeing
Sulphureous fluid his phantasies
The Eternal Prophet heavd the dark
bellows.
And turn'd restless the tongs; and the
hammer
Incessant beat; forging chains new & new
Numb'ring with links, hours days & years
3 The eternal mind bounded began to roll
Eddies of wrath ceaseless round & round
And the sulphureous foam surgeing thickIn Copy A, the letters "am" in "foam" are barely legible.
Settled, a lake, bright. & shining clear
White as the snow on the mountains cold
4 Forgetfulness. dumbness, necessity!
In chains of the mind locked up,
Like fetters of ice shrinking together
Disorganiz'd. rent from Eternity.
Los beat on his fetters of iron:
And heated his furnaces & pour'd
Iron sodor and sodor of brass
5. Restless turnd the immortal inchain'd
Heaving dolorous! anguish'd! unbearable
Till a roof shaggy wild inclos'd
In an orb, his fountain of thought.
6. In a horrible dreamful slumber;
Like the linked infer'nal chain;
A vast Spine writh'd in torment
Upon the winds; shooting pain'd
Ribs, like a bending cavern
And bones of solidness, froze,
Over all his nerves of joy.
And a first Age passed over,
And a state of dismal woe,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude male figures, with tormented expressions and their legs drawn up toward their chests, sit in or in front of a wall of upward-swirling flames (left) and a dome (right). The emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure on the left looks upward while holding his arms at his sides and resting his hands on his knees. The figure on the right sits with head tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side. If the figure on the right is Los, the round object at bottom right is probably one end of the "great hammer" that "fell from his hand" when he "shrunk from his task" (Plate 16, lines 22-24) after putting Urizen in chains. The figure on the left is shackled and chained around the ankles in this copy and thus may be Urizen. Just left of the background dome (St. Paul's of London or St. Peter's in Rome?) is a pillar or tower leaning in an arc to the left, perhaps based on the famous leaning tower of Pisa.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with tormented, pained expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits in or near a wall of upward-swirling flames. The emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure looks upward, mouth slightly open, while holding his arms at his sides and resting his hands on his knees. He is shackled and chained at the ankles. He may be Urizen after being enchained by Los.

A nude male, perhaps Los, with tormented or pained expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits before a dome and leaning column or tower. His head is tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side, where a hammer rests. His hair is flame-like.
The figure on the left is shackled and chained around the ankles. The chains are connected to large rings or links just above the lower margin of the plate.
The figure on the left sits within or in front of upward-swirling flames that extend toward the text and to the right above the other figure.
Behind the figure on the right is a dome (St. Paul's of London or St. Peter's in Rome?) and a pillar or tower leaning in an arc to the left, perhaps based on the famous leaning tower of Pisa.
If the nude figure on the right is Los, the object in the lower right corner is probably the end of his hammer resting on the ground.

lg.l: 7. From the caverns of his jointed Spine,
Down sunk with fright a red
Round globe hot burning deep
Deep down into the Abyss;
Panting: Conglobing, Trembling
Shooting out ten thousand branches
Around his solid bones.
And a second Age passed over,
And a state of dismal woe.
8. In harrowing fear rolling round;
His nervous brain shot branches
Round the branches of his heart.
On high into two little orbs
And fixed in two little caves
Hiding carefully from the wind,
His Eyes beheld the deep.
And, a third Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
9. The pangs of hope began,
In heavy pain striving. struggling.
Two Ears in close volutions.
From beneath his orbs of vision
Shot spiring out. and petrified
As they grew. And a fourth Age passed
And a state of dismal woe.
10. In ghastly torment sick;
Hanging upon the wind;

illustration.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man is seen from behind facing downward. His blonde hair streams back (or up) toward his feet. A beard, barely discernible from above along the edge of his jaw in some copies, makes it likely that this is Urizen. In beardless copies, the figure may be identified with Los. In this copy, there are slight suggestions of a beard. His body and left leg arc to the left; his right leg is bent toward the viewer, exposing the sole of his right foot. His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands, which in turn are braced on what may be rock, earth, or clouds at the bottom of the design. His left leg is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.

His arms are drawn back and his elbows are bent, as if the weight of his body is resting on his hands. His left leg is partly enveloped in a filmy, semi-transparent substance, perhaps clouds. His position, along with his streaming hair, suggests falling, floating, or hovering.

lg.l: Two Nostrils bent down to the deep;
And a fifth Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
11. In ghastly torment sick;
Within his ribs bloated round,
A craving Hungry Cavern:
Thence arose his channeld Throat.
And like a red flame a Tongue
Of thirst & of hunger appeard.
And a sixth Age passed over:The first letter of "Age" was written in acid-resist as both a lower-case "a" and an upper-case "A." Both letters were etched, and both print in Copy A.
And a state of dismal woe.
12. Enraged & stifled with torment
He threw his right Arm to the north
His left Arm to the south
Shooting out in anguish deep,
And his Feet stampd the nether Abyss
In trembling & howling & dismay.
And a seventh Age passed over;
And a state of dismal woe.
1. In terrors Los shrunk from his
task;
His great hammer fell from his hand.
His fires beheld, and sickening.
Hid their strong limbs in smoke.
For with noises ruinous loud;
With hurtlings & clashings & groans
The Immortal endur'd his chains,
Tho' bound in a deadly sleep.
2. All the myriads of Eternity;
All the wisdom & joy of life;
Roll like a sea around him.
Except what his little orbs
Of sight by degrees unfold.
3. And now his eternal life
Like a dream was obliterated
4. Shudd'ring, the Eternal Prophet smote
With a stroke, from his north to south
region
The bellows & hammer are silent now
A nerveless silence, his prophetic voice
Siez'd; a cold solitude & dark void
The Eternal Prophet & Urizen clos'd
5. Ages on ages rolld over them
Cut off from life & light frozen
Into horrible forms of deformity
Los suffer'd his fires to decay
Then he look'd back with anxious desirIn Copy A, the "e" at the end of "desire" did not print except for very small fragments.
But the space undivided by existence
Struck horror into his soul.
6. Los wept obscur'd with mourning:
His bosom earthquak'd with sighs;
He saw Urizen deadly black,
In his chains bound, & Pity began.
7. In anguish dividing & dividing
For pity divides the soul
In pangs eternity on eternity
Life in cataracts pourd down his
cliffs
The void shrunk the lymph into Nerves
Wand'ring wide on the bosom of night
And left a round globe of blood
Trembling upon the Void

lg.l: 8. The globe of life blood trembled
Branching out into roots;
Fib'rous, writhing upon the winds;
Fibres of blood. milk and tears;
In pangs. eternity on eternity,
At length in tears & cries imbodied
A female form trembling and pale
Waves before his deathy face
9, All Eternity shudderd at sight
Of the first female now separate
Pale as a cloud of snow
Waving before the face of Los
10. Wonder, awe, fear, astonishment
Petrify the eternal myriads,
At the first female form now separate

illustration.illusobjdesc: A tightly arranged group of three figures stands against a rocky cliff, perhaps covered by indeterminate vegetation on the left. The figures, from left to right, are (1) a nude woman with long hair who with her right arm is embracing, while looking down toward, (2) a nude child with short curly hair, probably male, seen from behind, who embraces the female with both arms; and (3) a bearded nude male, likewise looking down toward the child. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 22, line 28), hangs down the length of his body; its lower end terminates at his feet. The chain's upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest. He holds a large hammer with his right hand; his right arm, bent at the elbow, rests upon his right hand. The hammer rests upon a pedestal or anvil. The trio likely represents Enitharmon and Los with the child Orc.

component.illusobjdesc: Enitharmon, a nude woman with long hair, stands in contrapposto, right foot forward, while embracing and looking down toward Orc. Her head seems to touch the head of Los on the right.
Orc, a nude and probably male child with short, curly hair seen from behind standing in contrapposto, embraces his mother Enitharmon with both arms raised. His head is turned upward.

Los, a bearded nude male standing in contrapposto, looks down toward Orc. His head appears to touch the head of Enitharmon, who stands close beside him. A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 22, line 28) hangs down the length of his body. Its upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest. He holds a large hammer with his right hand; his right arm, bent at the elbow, rests atop the hammer.
A massive chain, probably "the Chain of Jealousy" (Plate 22, line 28) hangs down the length of Los's body. Its upper end is attached to a large shackle or belt around his chest.
Los holds a large hammer vertically. It rests on a pedestal or anvil.
Los's hammer rests on a pedestal or anvil.

The two figures may be Los and Enitharmon: "the first female now separate / Pale as a cloud of snow / Waving before the face of Los" (Plate 17, lines 12-15). The white area to the left of the female might represent smoke or clouds, or possibly just the sides of large rocks.

On the ground to the right sits a nude figure with long hair, probably male, perhaps Los, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head.
The white area to the left of the female might represent smoke or clouds, or possibly just the sides of large rocks.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils help fill the spaces at ends of short lines to the left of center. One tendril fills the space between stanzas (10-11, top left) and another helps fill the space around a chapter heading (chapter 6 in the left column). At the top, above both columns of text, the vine forks left and right. Detached leaves or stems are particularly prominent at the top of the right column. A few tendrils independent of the central vine, several generated as extensions of letters in the text, fill spaces in the right column. The serpentine extension of the "t" in "serpent" (line 30) and the loopy extension of the "s" at the end of "resistless" (line 48) are notable. Flanking the chapter 6 heading, two figures(?) hover horizontally, their arms extended.

lg.l: They call'd her Pity, and fled
11. "Spread a Tent. with strong cur-
-tains around them
"Let cords & stakes bind in the Void
That Eternals may no more behold them"
12. They began to weave curtains of
darkness
They erected large pillars round the Void
With golden hooks fastend in the pillars
With infinite labour the Eternals
A woof wove. and called it Science
1. But Los saw the Female & pitied
He embrac'd her, she wept, she refus'd
In perverse and cruel delight
She fled from his arms, yet he followd
2. Eternity shudder'd when they saw.
Man begetting his likeness,
On his own divided image.
3. A time passed over, the Eternals
Began to erect the tent;
When Enitharmon sick,
Felt a Worm within her womb.
4. Yet helpless it lay like a Worm
In the trembling womb
To be moulded into existence
5. All day the worm lay on her bosom
All night within her womb
The worm lay till it grew to a ser-
-pent
With dolorous hissings & poisons
Round Enitharmons loins folding,
6, Coild within Enitharmons womb
The serpent grew casting its scales,
With sharp pangs the hissings began
To change to a grating cry,
Many sorrows and dismal throes:
Many forms of fish, bird & beast
Brought forth an Infant form
Where was a worm before.
7. The Eternals their tent finished
Alarm'd with these gloomy visions
When Enitharmon groaning
Produc'd a man Child to the light,
8. A shriek ran thro' Eternity:
And a paralytic stroke;
At the birth of the Human shadow.
9. Delving earth in his resistless
way;
Howling, the Child with fierce flames
Issu'd from Enitharmon,
10. The Eternals, closed the tent
They beat down the stakes the cords

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three male figures, who may be the Eternals, are suspended, as if in a cloud, over a dark area, its surface curved like part of a globe. They may be erecting a tent, or at least drawing a curtain, between their world and Urizen's (Plate 19, lines 2-11). Between the group of figures above and the globe below are streaks of cloud and light that suggest sunrise or sunset. From the right the figures are: (1) the head of a male with long, white, flowing hair and beard and down-cast eyes, wearing a cloak or drapery of some sort over his left shoulder and arm; (2) a male, naked from the waist up, reaching down toward the earth with his left arm and hand, his fingers emitting slight indications of some substance, possibly drapery; (3) the head of a man with long, curly hair and beard and eyes staring downward.

component.illusobjdesc: Between the group of figures above and the globe below are streaks of cloud and light that suggest sunrise or sunset.

The head of an elderly male with long, slightly curly hair and beard appears just left of the central figure. He looks downward with staring, even bulging, eyes. There are no clear indications of clothing on the one visible part of his body, his right shoulder.

A male, perhaps braced on his right arm, bends forward and reaches down toward the dark globe with his left arm; his fingers emit streams of some substance, possibly drapery. He is nude from the waist up, but his lower back appears to be covered with a gown or drapery of some sort. His hair is short and somewhat curly.

The head of an old man with long, flowing white beard and eyes looking down appears right of the central figure. The end of his beard seems to touch the globe below. He wears a gown or drapery over the only visible parts of his body, his left shoulder and arm.
Three figures hover over a dark, curved part of a globe, possibly the earth.

From the central figure's fingers streams a substance that may be the fabric of the tent erected by the Eternals, its curtains, flesh, or Blakean streams of gore. In this copy, the representation of this substance is very minimal and looks more like drapery than something biological.

From the central figure's fingers streams a substance that might be the fabric of the tent erected by the Eternals, its curtains, flesh, or Blakean streams of gore. The representation of this object or substance is minimal in this copy, making identification difficult.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine separates the two columns of text from one another. Its tendrils and leaves, one loopy, others serpentine or flame-like, are extended to fill the spaces around short lines and at the end of the text on this plate. A flower or cluster of leaves, independent of the central vine, forms from an extension of the "d" at the end of "appear'd" (line 9). A single bird flies above "a winterly" in line 5.

lg.l: Thus the Eternal Prophet was divided
Before the death image of Urizen
For in changeable clouds and darkness
In a winterly night beneath.
The Abyss of Los stretch'd immense:
And now seen. now obscur'd to the eyes
Of Eternals, the visions remote
Of the dark seperation appear'd.
As glasses discover Worlds
In the endless Abyss of space.
So the expanding eyes of Immortals
Beheld the dark visions of Los.
And the globe of life blood trembling.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude male, facing forward but with his eyes looking upward, squats or sits at the center of a burst of flames. His position is severely contracted—legs drawn up tightly to his chest, arms raised at 135 degrees and bent with hands invisible behind his head. In this copy, he has a long, white beard and touches of white on his long, flame-like hair. These features associate him with Urizen.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male, facing forward but with his eyes looking upward, squats or sits at the center of a burst of flames. His position is severely contracted—legs drawn up tightly to his chest, arms raised at 135 degrees and bent with hands invisible behind his head. In this copy, he has a long, white beard and touches of white on his long, flame-like hair. The beard and evident age of the figure associate him with Urizen.
A nude male squats in the center of a burst of flames.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with an unusual number of tendrils tangled in the central area separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, and in a few instances generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (from top left, stanzas 10-11, 1-2, 2-3, 5-6, 7-8, 9-10), around all three of the chapter headings (at the top center and in each column), and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "e" of "the" in line 30 and the "U" of "Urizen" in line 35. In the margin at lower right, in lieu of vines, flame-like shapes (but darkly colored) are extended upward from the large design below into the spaces at the ends of lines that begin chapter 8.

lg.l: Stretch'd for a work of eternity;
No more Los beheld Eternity.
11. In his hands he siez'd the infant
He bathed him in springs of sorrow
He gave him to Enitharmon.
1, They named the child Orc, he grew
Fed with milk of Enitharmon
2. Los awoke her; O sorrow & pain!
A tight'ning girdle grew.
Around his bosom. In sobbings
He burst the girdle in twain,
But still another girdle
Opress'd his bosom, In sobbings
Again he burst it. Again
Another girdle succeeds
The girdle was form'd by day;
By night was burst in twain.
3. These falling down on the rock
Into an iron Chain
In each other link by link lock'd
4. They took Orc to the top of a
mountain.
O how Enitharmon wept!
They chain'd his young limbs to the
rock
With the Chain of Jealousy
Beneath Urizens deathful shadow
5. The dead heard the voice of the
child
And began to awake from sleep
All things, heard the voice of the child
And began to awake to life.
6. And Urizen craving with hunger
Stung with the odours of Nature
Explor'd his dens around
7. He form'd a line & a plummet
To divide the Abyss beneath.
He form'd a dividing rule:
8. He formed scales to weigh;
He formed massy weights;
He formed a brazen quadrant:
He formed golden compasses
And began to explore the Abyss
And he planted a garden of fruits
9, But Los encircled Enitharmon
With fires of Prophecy
From the sight of Urizen & Orc.
10. And she bore an enormous race
1. Urizen explor'd his dens
Mountain, moor. & wilderness,
With a globe of fire lighting his
journey
A fearful journey. annoy'd
By cruel enormities; forms

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man, presumably Urizen, with a beard crouches, supporting himself with his left knee and both hands on the ground. He is positioned at the mouth of a cave or in a cleft in a rock whose weight seems to bear down on his head and shoulders. His eyes would appear to be closed.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man, presumably Urizen, with a long, flowing beard crouches, supporting himself with his left knee and both hands on the ground. His eyes would appear to be closed. His right knee is prominent.
Urizen appears to be crouching in the mouth of a cave or a cleft in a rock surface.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a dark, mountainous landscape opening onto an area of gray sky, a fully gowned male with long, flowing beard, probably Urizen, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm extends forward with the palm of the hand vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light. At bottom right the head and front legs of a lion appear in shadowy profile. The illustration seems to depict the episode in which "Urizen explor'd his dens / Mountain, moor & wilderness / With a globe of fire lighting his / journey" (Plate 22, lines 52-55).

component.illusobjdesc: Urizen, as a fully gowned male with long, flowing beard, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm is extended with his palm vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe. His eyes appear to be looking down.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of gray sky.

With his right hand by his side Urizen holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine or flame-like or, in one instance between stanzas 4 and 5, its loopy tendrils and leaves (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, often generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between all the stanzas on this plate and around short lines. Some of the extensions of letters are particularly extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "n" of "Fuzon" in line 20. The extensions of the central vine that sprout left and right below the text and around Urizen's head have shapes that may suggest serpents with (on the right) open mouths. Three or four flying birds help fill the space between stanzas 1 and 2.

Some of the extensions of letters are extravagant, especially (in the right column) the "n" of "Fuzon" in line 20. lg.l: Of life on his forsaken mountains
2, And his world teemd vast enormities
Frightning: faithless; fawning
Portions of life; similitudes
Of a foot, or a hand, or a head
Or a heart, or an eye, they swam mis-
-chevous
Dread terrors! delighting in blood
3 Most Urizen sicken'd to see
His eternal creations appear
Sons & daughters of sorrow on mountains
Weeping! wailing! first Thiriel appear'd
Astonish'd at his own existence
Like a man from a cloud born, & Utha
From the waters emerging, laments!
Grodna rent the deep earth howling
Amaz'd! his heavens immense cracks
Like the ground parch'd with heat; then
Fuzon
Flam'd out! first begotten, last born.
All his eternal sons in like manner
His daughters from green herbs & cattle
From monsters, & worms of the pit.
4. He in darkness clos'd. view'd all his
race
And his soul sicken'd! he curs'd
Both sons & daughters; for he saw
That no flesh nor spirit could keep
His iron laws one moment.
5. For he saw that life liv'd upon
death

illustration.illusobjdesc: Before a paneled(?) door or wall raked diagonally upper left by a shadow, a child in a full gown stands with his hands raised as if in prayer. His mouth is open and eyes turned upward. Behind him, a dog, perhaps "The Dog at the wintry door" (Plate 26, line 3), stretched out in front of the door or wall holds its head raised vertically and mouth open as if howling.

component.illusobjdesc: Before a door or wall, a child, probably male, in a full gown stands with his hands clasped and raised as if in prayer. His mouth is open and his eyes are raised.
Behind a child, a dog—perhaps "The Dog at the wintry door" (Plate 26, line 3)—stretched out in front of the lower edge of the door or wall holds its head raised vertically, mouth open as if howling.
Before a paneled(?) door or wall raked diagonally upper left by a shadow are a dog and a child.
The door or wall is raked diagonally by a very dark shadow.

l.note: In Copy A, in the top right corner, only illegible fragments of two partially erased numbers are visible. The first of these numbers appears to be a "2."

objnote.p: Just above the beginning of the text and centered on the plate are a few printed marks that may have been intended as a heading. If so, Blake converted these letter forms on the copperplate into mere squiggles. These marks appear in a position where Blake wrote headings on 9 other plates in *The Book of Urizen*.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude and apparently female figures seem to be held in or emerging from the coils of giant worms or serpents; or, alternatively, the women may be the heads and upper bodies of the worms. The woman on the left has her right arm at her side and head tilted back and to the left. The serpent's coil wraps around her midriff, beneath which her body disappears. The woman to the right also faces to the left, her hands clutching her head. What might be the head of a third woman appears just to the left of the head of the woman upper right. The scene is set in the midst of mostly indeterminate vegetation. Leafy structures edge the bottom and right margin of the design. A fourth figure, scaly, with bat wings, faces down, her head partly obscuring the upper body of the woman clutching her head. Her long hair falls over her face. She is hunched over in a quasi-crawling position, a serpent coiled around her midsection. The women may be Urizen's daughters, who are born "from green herbs & cattle / From monsters, & worms of the pit" (Plate 24, lines 23-24).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude woman seen from the bosom up, has her right arm at her side and head tilted back and to the left. The coil of a worm or serpent wraps around her midriff, beneath which her body disappears. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.
A serpent-coiled nude woman, seen from the waist or hips up, looks up and off to the left, her hands clutching her head. She is probably one of Urizen's newly born daughters.
Just the face of a third figure, possibly female, might be indicated by the shapes just to the left of the head of the woman upper right.

Flanked by the other figures, a fourth woman, scaly and dark-skinned, with bat wings, faces down, her head partly obscuring the upper body of the female clutching her head. Her long hair cascades downward, covering her face. She is hunched over in a quasi-crawling position, a serpent coiled around her midsection. She is probably one of Urizen's daughters.
The scene is set in the midst of mostly indeterminate vegetation. Leafy structures edge the bottom and right margin of the design.
Giant worms or serpents, perhaps bat-winged, coil around human figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine (even snake-like below line 48), flame- like, or loopy leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, a few of these generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (6-7, 7-8, 8-9, 1-2, 2-3, 3-4), at the foot of the left column, and around short lines. The vine above the fourth stanza, lower right column, terminates in a flower. Between stanzas 5 and 6 in the left column is a row of at least four figures, and other figures appear in the left column between stanzas 7 and 8 and between 8 and 9; in the right column, there are two figures between stanzas 1 and 2. An indistinct shape—perhaps a caterpillar or chrysalis—appears at the top of the central vine, in the center just above the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A central vine separates the columns of text. Its serpentine (especially between stanzas 3 and 4 in the right column), flame-like, or loopy (after lines 3 and 10) leaves and tendrils (with other bits of vegetation independent of the central vine, a few of these generated as extensions of letters in the text) help fill the spaces between stanzas (6-7, 7-8, 8-9, 1-2, 2-3, 3-4), at the chapter break at the foot of the left column, and around short lines. The vine above the fourth stanza, lower right column, terminates in a flower.
Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5 and 6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of three or four human figures. The gowned one furthest to the right is hovering horizontally, arms extended.

Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5 and 6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of three or four human figures. The figure second from the right runs to the left with arm raised and leg extended backward.

Between stanzas 5 and 6 (lines 5 and 6), after two bits of vegetation(?), is a row of four human figures. Fourth from the right, a figure falls(?) upside down with arms raised horizontally and legs spread.
Between stanzas 7 and 8 (lines 21 and 22) a figure hovers with arms raised horizontally. Bits of drapery or a gown stream from the figure toward the left.
Between stanzas 1 and 2 (lines 35 and 36) two figures facing one another hover with their bodies horizontal and their arms extended toward one another. The legs on the right figure are spread.
Between stanzas 8 and 9 (lines 24 and 26) a gowned(?) figure hovers, facing down; its arms are extended.
An indistinct shape—perhaps a caterpillar or chrysalis—appears at the top of the central vine, in the center just above the text.

lg.l: The Ox in the slaughter house moans
The Dog at the wintry door
And he wept. & he called it Pity
And his tears flowed down on the winds
6. Cold he wander'd on high, over
their cities
In weeping & pain & woe!
And where-ever he wanderd in sorrows
Upon the aged heavens
A cold shadow follow'd behind him
Like a spiders web. moist, cold. & dim
Drawing out from his sorrowing soul
The dungeon-like heaven dividing
Where ever the footsteps of Urizen
Walk'd over the cities in sorrow.
7. Till a Web dark & cold, throughout all
The tormented element stretch'd
From the sorrows of Urizens soul

l.note: In Copy A, between lines 19 and 20, the line "And the Web is a Female in embrio" has been erased.

lg.l: None could break the Web, no wings
of fire.
8 So twisted the cords, & so knotted
The meshes: twisted like to the
human brain
-gion
9. And all calld it. The Net of Reli-
1. Then the Inhabitants of those Cities:
Felt their Nerves change into Marrow
And hardening Bones began
In swift diseases and torments,
In throbbings & shootings & grindings
Thro' all the coasts: till weaken'd
The Senses inward rush'd shrinking,
Beneath the dark net of infection.
2. Till the shrunken eyes clouded over
Discern'd not the woven hipocrisy
But the streaky slime in their heavens
Brought together by narrowing perceptions
Appeard transparent air; for their eyes
Grew small like the eyes of a man
And in reptile forms shrinking together
Of seven feet stature they remaind
3 Six days they. shrunk up from existence
And on the seventh day they rested
And they bless'd the seventh day, in sick
hope:
And forgot their eternal life
4. And their thirty cities divided
In form of a human heart
No more could they rise at will
In the infinite void, but bound down
To earth by their narrowing perceptions

illustration.illusobjdesc: An old man with full gown and long, flowing white beard and hair, presumably Urizen, sits or squats with eyes looking sharply downward, arms raised horizontally, and hands hanging down. His arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right. There is the suggestion of a halo—or at least an aura of light and a few beams—around his head. He is flanked by massive rope nets, one of which entangles his right shoulder. His left foot peeps out from his gown between the nets at the bottom of the design. The design probably depicts the "Web dark & cold" that "stretch'd / From the sorrows of Urizens soul / . . . / And all calld it The Net of Religion" (Plate 26, lines 17-26).

component.illusobjdesc: An old man with full gown and long, flowing white beard and hair, presumably Urizen, sits with eyes down, arms raised horizontally, and hands hanging down. His arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right. There is the suggestion of a halo—or at least an aura of light and a few beams to the right—around his head. He is flanked by massive rope nets, one of which entangles his right shoulder. His left foot peeps out (improbably, considering the way his legs seem to be placed) from his gown between the nets at the bottom of the design. His knees are prominent.
Urizen is flanked by massive rope nets, probably the "Net of Religion" (Plate 26, line 26), one of which entangles his right shoulder.
Urizen's arms appear to be resting on stone surfaces to left and right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: An unusually simple central vine divides the left from the right column of text. The vine has few extensions: a large single leaf or spiky flower at the end of line 9 and a sprig between stanzas 6 and 7. A few other bits of vegetation, independent of the central vine, are notable: a serpentine or flame-like tendril in the top right corner, a slender vine above the left column of text and running head, and an elaborate extension of the initial "T" in "The End" (after line 25). At the foot of the right column is an outstretched corpse.

component.illusobjdesc: A human body, probably a corpse, lies supine at the end of the right column of text.

An unusually simple central vine divides the left from the right column of text. The vine has few extensions: a large single leaf or spiky flower at the end of line 9 and a sprig between stanzas 6 and 7. A few other bits of vegetation, independent of the central vine, are notable: a serpentine or flame-like tendril in the top right corner, a slender vine extending above the left column of text and above the running head, and an elaborate extension of the initial "T" in "The End" (after line 25).

l.note: In Copy A, a number in the top right corner has been erased and is now illegible.

lg.l: They lived a period of years
Then left a noisom body
To the jaws of devouring darkness
5 And their children wept, & built
Tombs in the desolate places,
And form'd laws of prudence, and
call'd them
The eternal laws of God
6, And the thirty cities remaind
Surrounded by salt floods, now call'd
Africa: its name was then Egypt.
7. The remaining sons of Urizen
Beheld their brethren shrink together
Beneath the Net of Urizen;
Perswasion was in vain:
For the ears of the inhabitants,
Were wither'd, & deafen'd, & cold.
And their eyes could not discern,
Their brethren of other cities,
8. So Fuzon call'd all together
The remaining children of Urizen:
And they left the pendulous earth:
They called it Egypt. & left it.
9. And the salt ocean rolled englob'd
The End of the
book of UrizenIn Copy A, the first word in this line ("first"), as etched on the copperplate, was printed and then rubbed off in this impression.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object. The rounded shapes upper left and middle right may be stones or clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or perhaps strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, palms vertical and fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object.
The rounded objects left of the figure's left arm and right of his hips may be clouds or large stones.
